Greenland ice sheet

disintegration

Irreversible retreat of the ice sheet caused by rising temperatures

Sea level rise (up to 7m)

Abrupt increase in emissions of CO2 and methane through the thawing of frozen carbon-rich soils

Permafrost loss

Greenhouse gas release

Atlantic meridional

overturning circulation

breakdown

Shutdown of the AMOC caused by an increased influx of freshwater into the North Atlantic

Disruption to ocean ecosystem

Regional cooling

A shift in boreal forests, seeing expansion into tundra to the north and dieback to the south

Boreal forest

shift

Regional warming

Ecological shift

Nine “tipping points” where a changing climate could push parts of the Earth system into abrupt or irreversible change.

Tipping points

Impacts

Melting

Biome shift

Tipping points

Impacts

Circulation change

Amazon rainforest

dieback

Deforestation and hotter, drier conditions causing dieback of the rainforest and a shift towards savannah

Biodiversity loss

Decreased rainfall

Collapse of the ice sheet triggered by persistent grounding-line retreat in one sector, cascading to other sectors

West Antarctic ice

sheet disintegration

Sea level rise (up to 3m)

An abrupt change in Sahel rainfall, caused by a shift northwards (wetter) or southwards (drier) in the West African monsoon

West African

monsoon shift

Disruption to agriculture

Ecosystem change

A strengthening of the monsoon caused by rising CO2 emissions or a weakening as a result of high aerosol emissions

Disruption to agriculture

Indian monsoon shift

Greater rainfall extremes

Rising temperatures pushing warm water corals beyond tolerable levels of thermal stress into an alternative state dominated by macroalgae

Coral reef die-off

Ecosystem change

Losses to fisheries and tourism
